title: Before 2019, will the President, Vice President, White House Press Secretary, White House Chief of Staff, or Attorney General name a suspected author of the New York Times "Resistance" op-ed?
preds: Ain't nobody got time for that.
The news is too stale.  There is no political benefit to naming the author at this point.

This won't happen, even though an announcement by an Acting something would presumably count.  The Leader Of The Free World has too much else on his plate (sorry--almost said "mind") just now and is not able to think about more than one thing, if that many.

Given that the NYT has this OpEd as one of their top-read pieces of the year and that Gen Mattis' announced retirement has revived discussion of how many "adults there are in the room", I'm forecasting just a little higher than the crowd, as I think both of these things will wind DJT up into a tweet storm.

This article & related stories is coming up in lists of top stories in the NYT; I think that that will re-light DJT's fuse.
Since Gen Mattis announced his plans to retire in February, there's been renewed talk about the number of "adults in the room"; I think that that might also re-light DJT's fuse. EDIT:  One of the mistakes I make as a forecaster is that I get an idea in my head and build up a little narrative around it which all seems so plausible to me.  However, what makes this a mistake is that I often fail to test my theory/idea/narrative.  Well, this time I tried testing my little theory, and I got loudly shouted down,  so I'll be reducing this forecast back down.
Time is running out. Yet another display of the stunning incompetence of our government (FBI was told to investigate, wasn't it?).
No time left. This is old news so nothing new will come out.
No change, but wonder if Kelly does leave if there will be someone motivated to make a splash.
This is ancient history and not pertinent to Mueller probe, so it is long gone.
Dead issue, no motivation to do so now.
I'd actually forgotten about this, just like I'm pretty sure everyone in the administration has too.
Reduced to to time availability remaining in the year (6% Nov 9) to 3%. Probability raised to 4% as there is some chance the WH may want to release a distraction news piece.
Reducing due to passage of time. Was 10% on 9 Oct, should reach 0% on 31 Dec.

There is a 0% chance that the President, VP, Press Secretary, Chief of Staff, or Attorney General will name a suspected author of the NYT "resistance" op-ed. In September, right after the op-ed was released, President Trump had made a large deal of it, calling lots of attention to it and even asking for it to be investigated. In September 17th, the FBI director declined to state whether there would be an investigation, and since then, there has not been many (or any) updates on the topic. As things continue to escalate domestically and internationally, the attention on the author and the article has faded, showing that the likelihood of it being brought back up by the administration would be very low as it would just draw negative attention to it.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-justice-department-should-investigate-anonymous-op-ed-author/2018/09/07/b1eecd80-b2ba-11e8-a20b-5f4f84429666_story.html?utm_term=.65cb88d8e35a
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/fbi-director-declines-to-say-whether-it-will-investigate-author-of-anonymous-op-ed/2018/09/13/b3866270-b747-11e8-a7b5-adaaa5b2a57f_story.html?utm_term=.4ce9c66a2492
Seems to be too much else going on right now to focus on this particular issue right now. Doubt this happens before 2019.

Down 50% for (A) passage of time. (B) Between the optics at the US boarder and USG shutdown dynamics, the whole wall issue may shift toward DT's favor. If so, the win may be distracting enough that this issue gets lost (for a bit). Big win for Miller. Wonder if the US Congress might even tinker with the Posse Comitatus Act?

The new chief of staff when Kelly is sacked or the new attorney general, if installed soon enough to meet this deadline, might name somebody--not necessarily because it would be true, but as a show of loyalty by a newly anointed apostle.   Shows of loyalty are very big with the Current Incumbent. Truth, not so much.   Not moving my number up, though, because I'm pretty sure the Current Incumbent has forgotten about this and won't feel especially grateful for having it brought up again.
Trump is likely to let this sleeping dog lie. He has a record of only keeping a story alive if he gets enthusiastic feedback from his base.
Reducing due to passage of time. Was 10% on 9 Oct, should reach 0% on 31 Dec.

Echoing @cmeinel and @lsgold7. There is too much going on for the administration. In addition, the damage has already been done and naming the author now will put the op-ed back in the headlines and give the author a greater spotlight.

So they either have not looked or do not want to reveal who it is, and I do not think that will change. I think this is a senior person and the betrayal would be too much to acknowledge. This person will most likely identify himself after being expelled.

I am operating under the assumption that the person who wrote this is a republican.

I do not believe anyone will be named the suspected author of the NYT op-ed. While it truly was captivating for a brief moment in the news cycle, it is now old news. Additionally, there are numerous suspicious about the who the author could be, however, there seem to be no concrete answers (Washington Post). Moreover, I believe President Trump will likely want to keep the op-ed out of the press. At this point, there is no desire for him to bring it back into the news cycle. There have been hints "it is somebody in national security", however, there has been no further investigation into this belief (USA Today). I generally agree with pietrokc (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/779656) however I thought that DJT might use it as an excuse for firing Rod Rosenstein or someone else, but it seems that Rosenstein isn't going to be fired soon, nor Sessions, so I'm reducing my forecast.

Going in with basically no research. I look at the headlines and Twitter every day and I haven't heard anybody mention this op-ed in weeks. What are the incentives? The first four people named (President, Vice President, White House Press Secretary, White House Chief of Staff) are all "on the side of" the President, and can suffer a lot of punishment if they deviate from what he wants. So we can approximate their incentives by Trump's. Since everyone seems to have forgotten about this op-ed, I can't see how it would benefit Trump to bring it up again. Plus, by naming someone, he makes it more concrete / believable, and thus appears weak --- he cannot control his underlings, he doesn't fully control what happens in govt, etc. (I admit I didn't read the op-ed.) The other option is he names someone but as a writer of fiction --- e.g. he names Hillary Clinton as the author or whatever. I guess that could happen, but it seems a more fragile position than just maintaining that some abstract "enemy" wrote it. The latter isn't disprovable. Maybe if Trump was about to run in an election against opponent X, he could name X, but he's not. The Attorney General and Trump seem frequently at odds, so the former's incentives may not be close to Trump's. However, Google has just told me that Trump said Sessions should investigate who wrote the op-ed. So in hindsight I realize that the Attorney General probably can't name a suspect just from a gut feeling. He has to carry out an investigation, which doesn't even look like it's going to happen, and if it does, it'll take a while. Finally, there's probably some incentive for the party who wrote the op-ed to come forward --- a book deal? Fifteen minutes of fame? I don't think the NYTimes will out their own source, but the source might come out. So that knocks the chance down a bit further. Overall I want to say 10%.
I didn't realize the question resolves as NO if the author comes forward or the NYTimes outs him.  I give that a 1/3 chance, so discounting -16%.

I see the likelihood decreasing quite rapidly and currently see it to be 30% that an announcement will be made before the end of the year. Facts and assumptions I have made when predicting the probability of the author of the op-ed being named before the year ends.
1. I find it likely that this was a collective effort by a group of WH staffers that agreed that such an op-ed would be published by the NYT. I find it unlikely that it was a lone wolf acting on only her/his behalf as that would have left too much guessing room to other WH staffers meaning her/his identity could easily become known.
2. Possibility that it was no actually written by a (current) staffer - however that possibility low I would say not higher than 10%.
3. As mentioned in the op-ed piece the “resistance” member is a high-up in WH staff. Thus it is possible that the Trump administration could try to fire of dispose of the person(s) quietly in order not to give any new “ammunition” to the press.
4.  I assume it to be likely that there was high level precaution taken by both the NYT and the person(s) in the WH before the piece was published. I assume up to 10 people on both sides know the actual identity/identities of the person(s) who actually wrote the piece or gave it their candid approval. To me likely announcers are the following - President, WH Press Secretary and WH Chief of Staff
o	President most likely due to personality and probably seeing it as personal retribution to such betrayal. I also see it possible for the president to turn someone within the WH staff who has angered him into a scapegoat.
o	WH Press Secretary – possibly announcing it with candid approval from POTUS. However less likely that POTUS will give Sanders "the honours".
o	WH Chief of Staff – same as WHPS but additionally also wanting to show that has his house in order. Unlikely announcers – VP and Attorney General
o	VP – unlikely Pence will announce it. POTUS will likely want to do the "big reveal" if top tier going to make the announcement
o	AG – unlikely as Sessions has withdrawn from anything relating to governance that hasn’t to do with legal actions. According to experts DoJ has little legal justification into opening an investigation against the person unless she/he is a military official.

Daniel Hoffman ex Chief Moscow Station uch of my career at the CIA was spent focused on Russia. If there is one thing I learned it was that President Vladimir Putin, who directs the lion’s share of Russia’s military and intelligence actions against the United States, continues – like his Soviet predecessors – to view the U.S. as Russia’s “main enemy.” I have a high degree of confidence that Putin analyzed the op-ed with the greatest of interest. And I believe he then directed his intelligence services to collect corroborating intelligence and prepare options for weaponizing its content, as a part of Russia’s espionage and information attacks on the U.S. Russian intelligence would first focus on learning more about the author, whose identity is known to The New York Times. Russia would not rule out the possibility that not one but perhaps a number of Trump administration officials collaborated on the piece. The Kremlin is the most sophisticated purveyor of “fake news,” including social media and networking manipulation and amplification through bots. We should expect the Kremlin to mount a full-court press targeting not only Washington officials with access to the author’s identity, but also targeting The New York Times – both through human intelligence operations as well as intrusions in cyberspace. Keep in mind that Russian hackers successfully targeted the Democratic National Committee during the 2016 presidential campaign. The New York Times should be prepared to defend itself from a Russian onslaught of phishing and social engineering attacks. Russia no doubt desperately wants to know who in the administration is operating against the president. In “Essence of Decision: Explaining the Cuban Missile Crisis,” Graham Allison and Phillip Zelikow outline three approaches to understanding government behavior: ·         The rational actor model, where governments – like individuals – make the most rational decisions based on a cost and benefit analysis. ·         The organizational process model, which focuses on the standard operating procedures inherent to any bureaucracy. ·         The government politics model, which focuses on how the key “players” – both people and organizations – compete for influence. This best reflects the high priority Russian intelligence would attach to understanding how senior Trump administration officials relate to one another and the president. Understanding these internal dynamics – the alleged “two-track presidency” described in the New York Times op-ed – would help Russia understand and predict U.S. policy with the highest degree of confidence. For Russian intelligence it is not important whether the anonymous op-ed writer’s claim that senior Trump administration officials are working to frustrate parts of the president’s agenda is in fact true. It also does not matter if the op-ed is correct in saying that President Trump’s leadership style is “impetuous, adversarial, petty and ineffective.” Russia invented the term “disinformation.” The Kremlin is the most sophisticated purveyor of “fake news,” including social media and networking manipulation and amplification through bots. Russia’s goal is to sow cultural and political discord in the U.S. and degrade trust in our democratic institutions. Russia would eagerly insert these themes into its information operations with an eye towards degrading both the U.S. domestic political process as well as foreign governments’ trust in the Trump administration. Russian intelligence would seek to use its media platforms to sprinkle corroborating “evidence” to buttress the op-ed’s attacks on the president. Putin is always cognizant of the potential for an Arab Spring or Color Revolution to end his regime. So he would seek to influence brave Russian protesters not to look to the U.S. for inspiration in their struggle for liberty, freedom and democracy – all absent in Russia. Russian intelligence is ruthlessly focused on ensuring the anonymous op-ed is transformed into a Pandora’s Box, which might appear to be a gift to some of the president’s critics but becomes a Kremlin curse on us all. Daniel Hoffman is a Fox News contributor, and retired clandestine services officer and former chief of station with the Central Intelligence Agency.
